raw_text:
Blair moves to woo Jewish voters
 
 Tony Blair has pledged to "never, ever, ever" attack Tory leader Michael Howard over his Jewish beliefs.
 
 The prime minister told the Jewish Chronicle: "If you look at what I do, I attack Michael Howard politically." Mr Blair also distanced himself from recent Labour campaign posters featuring Mr Howard, which critics claimed were "anti-Semitic". These were "not intended to cause any offence to anyone on the Jewish community," Mr Blair insisted.
 
 One poster depicted Mr Howard and his shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin, who is also Jewish, as flying pigs. Another pictured the Tory leader swinging a pocket watch on a chain, which critics said echoed the Jewish money lender Shylock in Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice.
 
 Others compared the image to the character Fagin in Charles Dickens' Oliver Twist. Labour has since taken the designs of its website, saying members had preferred other designs. During his interview with the Jewish Chronicle, Mr Blair said: "I've been a very strong supporter of the Jewish community and Israel, and will always be so." Pressed on whether he would draw attention to Mr Howard's Jewish beliefs in an attempt to attract Muslim support, he replied: "The idea that I would allow anybody to make such a charge is outrageous. It's untrue. "If you look what I do, I attack Michael Howard politically. I would never, ever, ever attack him on that basis."
 
 Mr Blair also defended his party's attitude towards the Jewish community, pointing out that it was his government that had introduced the Holocaust Memorial Day. He added that Labour also aggressively fought all forms of racism.
 
 Neither the Conservatives nor the Liberal Democrats wished to comment on Mr Blair's words. The prime minister was speaking as London's Labour mayor Ken Livingstone remains embroiled in a row over comments he made to a Jewish reporter from the city's Evening Standard newspaper. Mr Blair repeated calls for the mayor to apologise for likening the reporter, Oliver Finegold, to a concentration camp guard. Mr Livingstone "should have withdrawn the comment immediately" once he realised the journalist was Jewish, said Mr Blair. "I'm sure that is what in truth he wants to do. Well, he should do it." Mr Livingstone has said he could not sincerely say sorry for the comments he made, and claims he has been targeted by the newspaper. He conceded his comments may have been offensive but were not racist, and said earlier this week he would not apologise even if Mr Blair asked.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair pledges to support Jewish voters and distance himself from criticism of Labour's campaign posters featuring Conservative leader Michael Howard, claiming they were "not intended to cause any offence" despite being compared to anti-Semitic images.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair pledged not to attack Michael Howard over his Jewish beliefs, saying he attacks him politically instead.
Blair defended Labour's attitude towards the Jewish community, citing Holocaust Memorial Day and fighting racism.
Meanwhile, London's Labour mayor Ken Livingstone was criticized for comments likening a reporter to a concentration camp guard, with Blair calling for an apology.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair defended himself against accusations of anti-Semitism in Labour's political campaign materials while reaffirming support for the Jewish community.

He distanced himself from campaign posters depicting Michael Howard and suggested that his attacks on Howard are purely political, rejecting any link between his politics and attacking Howard's religion.
He also highlighted Labour's commitment to fighting racism and promoting Holocaust Memorial Day.
The controversy involves Tony Blair's public calls for Ken Livingstone to apologize for comparing a Jewish reporter to a concentration camp guard.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In an interview with The Jewish Chronicle, Prime Minister Tony Blair has rejected calls to attack Tory leader Michael Howard about his Jewish beliefs.
Blair maintains his support for the Jewish community and Israel while stressing that his government "introduced the Holocaust Memorial Day" as a measure to honor its history.

He has defended Labour's stance towards the Jewish community, arguing they were his government that introduced the Holocaust Memorial Day and highlighted their aggressive fight against all forms of racism.
Neither the Conservatives nor the Liberal Democrats wish to comment on Blair's words.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair pledged to never attack Michael Howard over Jewish beliefs, distancing himself from Labour campaign posters featuring Howard, which critics claimed were anti-Semitic.
Blair also defended his government's Holocaust Memorial Day initiative and the party's stance against racism.
He reiterated that his attacks on Howard are political rather than based on religion or ethnicity.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair pledged never to attack Michael Howard over his Jewish beliefs.
Despite Labour campaign posters depicting Howard as flying pigs or wielding a Shylock-like pocket watch, Blair insisted they were meant without offense.
He supported the Jewish community and Israel strongly, stating he would not draw attention to Howard’s Jewish identity to appeal to Muslim voters.
Blair defended his party's attitude towards Jews, highlighting their introduction of Holocaust Memorial Day.
However, he criticized Ken Livingstone for remarks comparing a Jewish reporter to a concentration camp guard, urging him to apologize.

tinyllama:1.1b:
Leaked Labour Leadership Memo: Jewish Vote Reserved for Members Over New Labour MP, Michael Howard

Tony Blair has pleaded with Labour voters to support the party's next leader, vowing never to attack Torrey leader Michael Howard over his Jewish beliefs.
The prime minister told the Jewish Chronicle that his approach towards the Jewish community was firmly grounded in an unwavering commitment to supporting the community and its issues.
He noted that Labour has introduced Holocaust Memorial Day, a policy he credited to his government for successfully attributing Israel's establishment to Hitler's persecution of Jews.
Blair also defended Labour's attitude towards the Jewish community, insisting that they are "strongly supportive" of Israel and have never hesitated in attacking the Holocaust.
The prime minister further noted that the party's next leader should not be judged based solely on his or her personal views, but rather the political platform to which the candidate belongs.

In the aftermath of Labour's recent campaign poster featuring Michael Howard and his shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin swinging pigs, Blair criticized Labour MPs for taking a "political view" and arguing that a new candidate could have avoided creating controversy by drawing the right comparison between Howard and the Jewish money lender, William Shakespeare's Shylock.

Despite insisting that the party will not draw a comparison between Howard and the Torrey community leader, the Labour leader hinted at his support for Muslim voters by stating that he would be "very happy" if his party was able to win over Muslim support in next year's general election.

The Labour leadership memo also touched on the Jewish-Muslim divide in UK politics and urged the party to "do something" about it, citing its success at attaining a 20% Muslim vote share in last month's by-election for the Torrey seat as an example of how winning the community's support could lead to a more positive political discourse.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text describes Tony Blair's response to the Jewish community regarding his political stance on their issues.
According to the text, Blair stated that his government has introduced the Holocaust Memorial Day, and that Labour has always defended the Jewish community against accusations of racism.
Additionally, he argued that the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats do not wish to comment on his words.
phi:2.7b: Tony Blair promises to never attack Michael Howard over his Jewish beliefs, distancing himself from recent Labour campaign posters that some found anti-Semitic.
He insists these designs were not intended to cause offense and emphasizes his support for the Jewish community and Israel.
He also defends his party's attitude towards racism, pointing out that it was his government that introduced Holocaust Memorial Day.
The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats did not comment on his words, while London's Labour mayor Ken Livingstone is embroiled in a controversy over comments he made to a Jewish reporter.
Mr Blair calls for the mayor to apologize and says he would do so himself if asked.

The prime minister also defended his government's attitude towards the Jewish community, reiterating his support for Holocaust Memorial Day and aggressive fight against all forms of racism.

He also defended his government's introduction of Holocaust Memorial Day and mentioned that Labour aggressively fights all forms of racism.
Despite the controversy over recent Labour campaign posters allegedly portraying Jews negatively, Blair insisted they were not intended to cause any offence.
London's Labour mayor, Ken Livingstone, is still embroiled in a row over comments he made to a Jewish reporter, with Blair calling for an apology.

He distanced himself from Labour campaign posters accused of anti-Semitism, insisting they were not meant to offend the Jewish community.
Blair reaffirmed his strong support for the Jewish community and Israel, rejecting claims that he would use Howard’s faith to gain Muslim support.
He highlighted Labour’s efforts against racism, including introducing Holocaust Memorial Day.
Meanwhile, Blair urged London Mayor Ken Livingstone to apologize for comparing a Jewish reporter to a concentration camp guard, though Livingstone refused, insisting his comments were not racist.
Neither the Conservatives nor the Liberal Democrats commented on Blair’s statements.

He also mentions Labour's introduction of Holocaust Memorial Day and aggressive stance against all forms of racism.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair has pledged to never criticize Michael Howard's Jewish faith in political attacks.

He distanced himself from controversial Labour campaign posters, stating they were not meant to offend the Jewish community and emphasized his long-standing support for Israel and the Jewish community.

Blair defended his party's record, including the introduction of Holocaust Memorial Day, and criticized Ken Livingstone, London's Labour mayor, for not apologizing to a Jewish reporter after likening him to a concentration camp guard.
Despite repeated calls from Blair, Livingstone has refused to retract his comments, claiming they were not racist and that he wouldn't apologize even if the prime minister asked.
